content.raw:
(1) Those lines are never reached, so I removed them.
(2) Your version is correct.
(3) numpy.random.choice [was added in numpy/1.7.0](http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.random.choice.html) . Using it adds an unnecessary dependence on this version of numpy. @hoffman , what do you think of using the base python function? In any case, this change is independent of the rest of the GMM changes.
(4) Those variables are used only for this piece of code. I think either one is equivalent.
(5) You're right, this piece of code is all messed up. You should change it so that a Genome object is opened only inside of make_continuous_cells(). You may need to refactor the control flow of make_continous_cells() and make_continous_cells_simple() to make this work.
(6) Yes, good catch.

Thanks!
Max
content.html:
(1) Those lines are never reached, so I removed them. (2) Your version is correct. (3) numpy.random.choice was added in numpy/1.7.0 . Using it adds an unnecessary dependence on this version of numpy. @hoffman , what do you think of using the base python function? In any case, this change is independent of the rest of the GMM changes. (4) Those variables are used only for this piece of code. I think either one is equivalent. (5) You're right, this piece of code is all messed up. You should change it so that a Genome object is opened only inside of make_continuous_cells(). You may need to refactor the control flow of make_continous_cells() and make_continous_cells_simple() to make this work. (6) Yes, good catch.

Thanks! Max

pull_request.title: Resubmit the mixtures of Gaussians code

pullrequest.title: Resubmit the mixtures of Gaussians code

content.raw:
Which additional fixes are you referring to exactly? These are the only differences I can find:

(1)  Lines 670-672 in yours. In particular, I did not take out the lines

```
#!python

-        elif self.zscore:
-            tracks_means = genome.means
-            tracks_vars = genome.vars
```

because I was not sure of their purpose yet, hence the original question in this thread. 

(2) Additionally, your changes to the function calls in line 692-695:


```
#!python

         with Genome(self.genomedata_names[0]) as genome:
             observations.locate_windows(genome)
             self.windows = observations.windows
             # XXX: does this need to be done before save()?
             self.subset_metadata()
-            
-            observations.save(genome)
+
+        observations.save()
```

are different from mine in that I preserved the original code (before this GMM patch), which should be:


```
#!python

        observations = Observations(self)

        # Use the first genomedata archive for locating windows
        with Genome(self.genomedata_names[0]) as genome:
            observations.locate_windows(genome)

        self.windows = observations.windows
        # XXX: does this need to be done before save()?
        self.subset_metadata()
        observations.save()
```
In particular, I think you have an extra indent in the last 3 lines of the ```with``` block, and it makes the code quite different.

(3) In addition, you have imported python's random module, which we removed in an earlier patch (so it should be re-replaced by ```import numpy.random```) because it was not seeded correctly, and rather than seeding two different RNGs, we chose to only seed one (numpy.random). 

(4) The other big difference is that in lines 656-658, you have done:


```
#!python

+            tracks_num_datapoints = []
+            tracks_sums = []
+            tracks_sums_squared = []
```

whereas I tried to check if track_sums already existed (so as to preserve the original code in this patch):

```
#!python


+                        if track_sums is None:
+                            tracks_sums = [0]*genome.num_tracks_continuous
+                            tracks_num_datapoints = [0]*genome.num_tracks_continuous
+                            tracks_sums_squared = [0]*genome.num_tracks_continuous
```

This is open to being replaced by a better check if there is one, however.

(5) Also, you chose to zip track_indexes and genomedata_names in a zipper, which is redundant since I don't think we actually use the track_index anywhere. I have bypassed this by simply doing ```for genomedata_name in genomedata_names``` in line 659 of my patch.

(6) In addition, I think in lines 693-694 in your patch,

```
#!python


                 chromosome = genome[chrom]
                 seq_cells = self.make_seq_cells(chromosome, start, end)
```

should be 

```
#!python

+                with Genome(genomedata_name) as genome:
+                    chromosome = genome[chrom]
+                    seq_cells = self.make_seq_cells(chromosome, start, end)
```

as in the original pre-GMM code:

```
#!python

                with Genome(genomedata_name) as genome:
                    chromosome = genome[chrom]
                    seq_cells = self.make_seq_cells(chromosome, start, end)
```

Aside from these 6 things, I do not see any additional differences in yours. Please let me know if I have missed any. Thanks!
content.html:
Which additional fixes are you referring to exactly? These are the only differences I can find:

(1) Lines 670-672 in yours. In particular, I did not take out the lines

-        elif self.zscore:
-            tracks_means = genome.means
-            tracks_vars = genome.vars

because I was not sure of their purpose yet, hence the original question in this thread.

(2) Additionally, your changes to the function calls in line 692-695:

         with Genome(self.genomedata_names[0]) as genome:
             observations.locate_windows(genome)
             self.windows = observations.windows
             # XXX: does this need to be done before save()?
             self.subset_metadata()
-            
-            observations.save(genome)
+
+        observations.save()

are different from mine in that I preserved the original code (before this GMM patch), which should be:

        observations = Observations(self)

        # Use the first genomedata archive for locating windows
        with Genome(self.genomedata_names[0]) as genome:
            observations.locate_windows(genome)

        self.windows = observations.windows
        # XXX: does this need to be done before save()?
        self.subset_metadata()
        observations.save()

In particular, I think you have an extra indent in the last 3 lines of the with block, and it makes the code quite different.

(3) In addition, you have imported python's random module, which we removed in an earlier patch (so it should be re-replaced by import numpy.random) because it was not seeded correctly, and rather than seeding two different RNGs, we chose to only seed one (numpy.random).

(4) The other big difference is that in lines 656-658, you have done:

+            tracks_num_datapoints = []
+            tracks_sums = []
+            tracks_sums_squared = []

whereas I tried to check if track_sums already existed (so as to preserve the original code in this patch):

+                        if track_sums is None:
+                            tracks_sums = [0]*genome.num_tracks_continuous
+                            tracks_num_datapoints = [0]*genome.num_tracks_continuous
+                            tracks_sums_squared = [0]*genome.num_tracks_continuous

This is open to being replaced by a better check if there is one, however.

(5) Also, you chose to zip track_indexes and genomedata_names in a zipper, which is redundant since I don't think we actually use the track_index anywhere. I have bypassed this by simply doing for genomedata_name in genomedata_names in line 659 of my patch.

(6) In addition, I think in lines 693-694 in your patch,

                 chromosome = genome[chrom]
                 seq_cells = self.make_seq_cells(chromosome, start, end)

should be 

+                with Genome(genomedata_name) as genome:
+                    chromosome = genome[chrom]
+                    seq_cells = self.make_seq_cells(chromosome, start, end)

as in the original pre-GMM code:

                with Genome(genomedata_name) as genome:
                    chromosome = genome[chrom]
                    seq_cells = self.make_seq_cells(chromosome, start, end)

Aside from these 6 things, I do not see any additional differences in yours. Please let me know if I have missed any. Thanks!

pullrequest.title: Resubmit the mixtures of Gaussians code

content.html:
@rcwchan :

I made some changes that should fix this patch in the case of multiple genomedata archives. Unfortunately, after about 30 minutes of messing with my environment, I could not get this version of Segway working, so I haven't tested these changes. There are almost certainly bugs -- if you're having trouble fixing them, let me know and I'll try to help.

Briefly, here is what I did: The previous patch changed observations.save() to take a Genomedata object as input, and passed the genomedata object opened in run.save_gmtk_output() to this function. This change doesn't work in the case of multiple genomedata archives. I removed the "genome" argument from observations.save() (as well as from observations,write() ). Instead, I opened the Genomedata object within observations.write(), in the part of the code that computes tracks_means and tracks_vars for the purpose of computing zscores. This change should make the code work with multiple genomedata archives again. It's possible it still doesn't work with concatenated input (i.e. multiple worlds) -- you may want to test that.

content.html:
@mlibbrecht : Thank you very much. Convergence also seems to take a very long time (even simpleseg appears to be going to ~60 rounds), is that normal/expected?

Did Shiqi (or whoever was working on this) leave behind any notes, perchance, on what exactly they were doing with this? There aren't any comments, unfortunately, and it is difficult to get a picture of what is being done overall. I would like to fully understand what is happening before I commit any patches for multiple datasets, but it's a bit difficult to decipher.

Thanks in advance.

content.raw: Upon some inspection, it looks like this is a pseudocount for training the mixture distribution weights. @shiqi could you email ask Oscar to ask him if this is correct? If so, this should be a Segway command-line parameter. Could you change this? Let's use 1 as the default (rather than 100). Similar to the transition pseudocount, this pseudocount is aimed at avoiding local optima.
content.html: Upon some inspection, it looks like this is a pseudocount for training the mixture distribution weights. @shiqi could you email ask Oscar to ask him if this is correct? If so, this should be a Segway command-line parameter. Could you change this? Let's use 1 as the default (rather than 100). Similar to the transition pseudocount, this pseudocount is aimed at avoiding local optima.
